sen.j: 『入出二門偈（にゅうしゅつにもんげ）』とは、親鸞が著わした偈頌（げじゅ）である。
sen.e: The term "Nyushutsu Nimonge" refers to a gatha (poetic verse of a scripture) written by Shinran.

sen.j: 世親（てんじん）の『無量寿経優婆提舎願生偈』と、それを解釈した曇鸞・道綽・善導の解釈を讃嘆したものである。
sen.e: In this verse, he admired "Muryoju-kyo Ubadaisha Ganshoge" ([Vasubandhu's] Upadeśa on the Sūtra of Immeasurable Life) by Tenjin (Seshin) (Vasubandhu) and commentaries on it by Donran (Tanluan), Doshaku (Daochuo) and Zendo (Shandao).

sen.j: 世親と曇鸞の解釈を中心に、ことに世親の「五念門」を中心に(している)。
sen.e: He commented mainly on the writings by Tenjin and Donran, especially on gonenmon (Five Practice-Gates of Mindfulness) by Tenjin.

sen.cmt: Gonenmon にシングルクォーテーションを追記しました。

sen.j: 礼拝・讚嘆・作願（さがん）・観察（かんざつ）に応じる近門・大会衆門・宅門・屋門の入の四門と、回向に応える園林遊戯地門の出の第五門の五つの功徳門をあわせて「入出二門」として解釈する。
sen.e: Five meritorious gates consisting of four entries, namely, gon mon (proximate entry), daie shumon (entry of the great assembly), taku mon (entry of one's abode) and oku mon (room entry) for raihai (reverence), santan (admiration), sagan (making the vow) and kanzatsu (meditation), and the fifth gate, namely, onrin yuge jimon (entry out into wandering in the forest) for eko (dedication of merit), were integrated into 'nyushutsu nimon' (two gates of entering and leaving), on which he commented in this verse.

sen.e: The Five Meritorious Gates consisting of four entry gates, Gon mon (proximate entry), Daie shumon (entry of the great assembly), Taku mon (entry of one's abode) and Oku mon (room entry) for the purpose of raihai (reverence), santan (admiration), sagan (making the vow) and kanzatsu (meditation), and an exit gate, onrin yuge jimon (exit to wander in the forest) for the purpose of eko (dedication of merit), were integrated into 'Nyushutsu Nimon' (Two Gates of Entering and Leaving), on which he commented in this verse.

sen.j: 本来、往生する人の修行として論じられていたものを、親鸞はすべて法蔵菩薩が修行し終わったものであると論じた。
sen.e: While they had been originally argued as subjects for practitioners of austerities to be reborn in the Pure Land, Shinran argued that Hozo bosatsu (Dharmakara Bodhisattva) had finished practicing all of them.

sen.e: While they had been originally argued as subjects for practitioners of austerities in order to be reborn in the Pure Land, Shinran argued that Hozo bosatsu (Dharmakara Bodhisattva) had finished practicing all of them.
